sn41.4:4.1: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
sn41.4:4.2: Then Citta the householder went up to them,
sn41.4:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn41.4:4.5: “Sirs, may the senior mendicants please accept my offering of tomorrow’s meal in my barn.”
sn41.4:4.7: Then, knowing that the senior mendicants had accepted, Citta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled them, keeping them on his right, before leaving.
sn41.4:4.8: Then when the night had passed, the senior mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, went to Citta’s barn,
sn41.4:4.9: and sat down on the indicated seats.
sn41.4:5.1: Then Citta served and satisfied the senior mendicants with his own hands with delicious milk-rice made with ghee.
sn41.4:5.2: When the senior mendicants had eaten and washed their hands and bowls, they got up from their seats and left.
sn41.4:5.3: Citta instructed that the remainder of the food be distributed, then followed behind the senior mendicants.
sn41.4:5.4: Now at that time the heat was sweltering.
sn41.4:5.5: And those senior mendicants walked along as if their bodies were melting, as happens after a meal.
sn41.4:6.1: Now at that time Venerable Mahaka was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.
sn41.4:6.2: Then Venerable Mahaka said to the senior venerable:
sn41.4:6.3: “Wouldn’t it be nice, sir, if a cool wind blew, a cloud canopy formed, and a gentle rain drizzled down?”
sn41.4:7.1: “It would indeed be nice, Reverend Mahaka.”
sn41.4:7.2: Then Mahaka used his psychic powers to will that a cool wind would blow, a cloud canopy would form, and a gentle rain would drizzle down.
sn41.4:7.4: “The most junior mendicant in this Saṅgha has such psychic power!”
sn41.4:7.5: When they reached the monastery, Mahaka said to the senior venerable:
sn41.4:7.10: Then the senior mendicants entered their dwellings,
sn41.4:7.11: and Mahaka entered his own dwelling.
sn41.4:8.1: Then Citta went up to Mahaka,
sn41.4:8.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn41.4:8.4: “Sir, please show me a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.”
sn41.4:8.5: “Well, then, householder, place your upper robe on the porch and spread a handful of grass on it.”
sn41.4:8.6: “Yes, sir,” replied Citta, and did as he was asked.
sn41.4:8.7: Mahaka entered his dwelling and latched the door. Then he used his psychic powers to will that a flame shoot out through the keyhole and the chink in the door, and it burned up the grass but not the upper robe.
sn41.4:8.8: Then Citta shook out his upper robe and stood to one side, shocked and awestruck.
sn41.4:8.9: And then Mahaka came out of his dwelling and said to Citta:
sn41.4:9.4: I hope Venerable Mahaka is happy here in Macchikāsaṇḍa,
sn41.4:9.5: for the Wild mango Grove is lovely.
sn41.4:9.6: I’ll make sure that Venerable Mahaka is provided with robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”
sn41.4:9.7: “That’s nice of you to say, householder.”
sn41.4:9.8: Then Mahaka set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robes, left Macchikasaṇḍa,
